text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

Apple Computers yesterday revealed plans for a completely new operating system, a strategy that it hopes will halt the disastrous slide in its sales and share price. The company, which has 20 million customers worldwide, including 500,000 in Australia, said the new system will not be available for another 18 months. Page 1.

InTech Consulting's annual survey of 39 superannuation managers has listed BNP Investment Management (Australia) Ltd as the top-ranked manager for 1996. The survey saw four out of the top five-ranked managers were smaller managers, with Hambros Hopkins, Maple-Brown Abbott and Portfolio Partners joining BNP at the top. The other spot was taken by GIO. Page 1.

The latest figures from EL Consulting released yesterday showed demand for executives had fallen a further two per cent in December, seeing it at a two-and-a-half year low. EL Consulting managing director Grant Montgomery said executive demand, a key indicator of general employment demand, looked likely to continue to fall until the middle of 1997. Page 5.

Canada's Indian Affairs and Northern Development Minister Ronald Irwin announced BHP has signed the necessary mine leases and obtained final environmental approvals to begin construction of its A$1.1 billion Lac de Gras diamond mine in Canada's North West Territories in April. Page 15.

As Highlands Gold Ltd attempts to bed down an A$160 million underwriting agreement by tomorrow, it yesterday released encouraging drill results from its Frieda-Nena copper-gold project in Papua New Guinea. Highlands managing director Ian Goddard said the results "reinforce the values of the project". Page 15.

HIH Winterthur chief executive Ray Williams says the company's acquisition of Colonial Mutual's General Insurance Company will see it clearly placed as the Australian market leader in the provision of general insurance products through banks and other finncial institutions. Page 16.
THE AUSTRALIAN

The Australian dollar dropped to two-month lows yesterday as the country's financial markets were dominated by a growing conviction of a further cut in interest rates by the Reserve Bank, as rumours spread that the RBA plans an unscheduled board meeting for later in the month. Page 21.

In a submission to the Wallis inquiry into Australia's financial system, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which has the highest number of customers in the country, has rejected moves to introduce deposit-protection insurance. The submission has also criticised the National Australia Bank Ltd for its efforts to allow non-banks full entry into the financial system. Page 21.

Financial services group Colonial will form a strategic alliance and distribution deal with general insurer HIH Winterthur, a move that will see the soon-to-be-listed Colonial group form a strong new force in insurance and banking. HIH will buy Colonial' existing general insurance subsidiary and all Colonial staff will be offered jobs by the new owner. Page 21.

AWA managing director John Rouse said yesterday his company was interested in purchasing the New South Wales Totaliser Agency Board if the publicly-owned body was privatised as expected. Rouse said AWA would bid for the 75 per cent part of the TAB that wuld be offered to private shareholders. Page 21.

National Australia Bank spokesman Hadyn Park said yesterday the Bank reported a 280 per cent rise in the use of its telephone banking services over the past year. Park said the Bank's research shows people prefer banking by telephone and that customers are beginning to understand the benefits of phone banking. Page 21.

As BHP has signed a crucial environmental agreement and long-term land and water leases for the A$1.1 billion Lac de Gras diamond project in Canada's Northwest Territories, work on the site of the world's richest unexploited diamond deposit may be stalledby the late arrival of winter in the Arctic tundra. Page 23.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

While retailers suffered disappointing trading conditions in the lead up to Christmas, the experience of other industries over the festive season also provides anecdotal evidence that Australia's economy is in bad health. While consumer spending was low in retail, discounting on new homes and cars and a shift by holidaymakers to budget accommodation are some signs of a slow start to the new year by the economy. Page 16.

A rise in nickel and copper prices and in the share price of News Corp saw the All Ordinaries index jump 14.3 points to 2415 as investors speculated about another cut in interest rates as a result of the weaker economy. Miners were driven high by increased prices, with WMC adding 19 cents, BHP up to A$17.95 and CRA rising 11 cents to A$19.55. Page 16.

The Reserve Bank was forced to deny a rumour yesterday that it had called a special meeting to consider further cutting national interest rates, as speculation over interest rate cuts dominated financial markets. The best indicator of interest rate levels, the implied yield on the March bank bill future contract, fell seven basis points to 5.74 per cent. Page 16.

The InTech Consulting survey of wholesale fund managers shows Australia's superannuation fund managers achieved an average return of 11.1 per cent in 1996, led by good performances from small funds as larger funds, such as AMP and Commonwealth Funds Managment, performed below average. The survey found the top performer in 1996 was Banque Nationale de Paris. Page 16.

Concerns over the long-term future of the retail industry pushed clothing and homewares group Country Road's shares down 28 cents to A$1.40 and clothing group Just Jeans down 15 cents to A$1.65, though it had hit a low of A$1.60. Both companies issued prfit downgrades of around 50 per cent on Tuesday. Page 16.

A dramatic drop in the price of gold may see Australia's larger goldminers pouncing on weaker companies, as the slide in price has opened opportunities for takeovers at unexpectedly low prices. The drop in the price of gold may also see many planned new projects unable to get off the ground until the price recovers. Page 17.
THE AGE

Following a sluggish six months for Australia, analysts have downgraded their earnings forecasts for the current financial year. Continuing weak consumer demand, lower commodity prices, a stronger currency and increased competition from imported goods ar expected to have forced the radical revision in Australia. Page B1.

BHP has won critical environmental and water licence agreements for its A$841 million Lac de Gras project in Canada, boosting the company's drive to become a big diamond producer in the second half of 1998. At forecast production levels, Lac de Gras would account for about 10 per cent of the annual sales of rough diamonds by the De Beers-controlled Central Selling Organisation. Page C1.

Despite total new vehicle sales for 1996 reaching the second-highest figure on record, 650,049, the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries is forecasting a 1997 total of only 630,000, claiming that "on an international comparison, the Australian new vehicle market should be closer to 700,000 units." Page C1.

Pacific Dunlop will today learn the details of a class action filed in the Federal Court on behalf of as many as 1200 Australian recipients of allegedly faulty pacemaker leads. The case could cost Pacific Dunlop millions and is believed to be the first cass action brought against the company over the leads outside North America. Page C1.

Following profit warnings from Country Road and Just Jeans, the executive director of the New South Wales branch of the Retail Trades Association, Bill Healey, attacked clothing retailers for failing to respond to changes in the economy and population, claiming that the issues were clearly not cyclical. Page C1.

Gold made a comeback yesterday after four days of battering, with the Gold Index regaining 15 points or 0.9 per cent to 1722 points. However, investors are still nervous about gold's short-term direction amid fears that European central banks are plannin big gold sales to boost their currencies before unification in 1999. Page C2.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
